titleStmt.title: The fourth of September. Newes from sundry places, both forraine and domestique From Venice, Rome, Spaine, France, Naples, the Palatinate, and the Low-Countries. A relation of Count Mansfeilds progresse, (his battaile with Gonsalo in his passage) till his arriuall at Breda, with the Duke of Brunswicke his valiant pursuit of Gonsalo, (being wounded) and the slaughter of 500. of his men, and the taking of certaine waggons, and Gonsales owne coath. Whereunto is added, a true and certaine report, of the lamentable shipwracke which happened at Plimoth in Deuonshire, on Munday the 19th. of August last past, with other great harme done elsewhere, by lightning and thunder on the same day.

titleStmt.title: The fourth of September. Newes from sundry places, both forraine and domestique From Venice, Rome, Spaine, France, Naples, the Palatinate, and the Low-Countries. A relation of Count Mansfeilds progresse, (his battaile with Gonsalo in his passage) till his arriuall at Breda, with the Duke of Brunswicke his valiant pursuit of Gonsalo, (being wounded) and the slaughter of 500. of his men, and the taking of certaine waggons, and Gonsales owne coath. Whereunto is added, a true and certaine report, of the lamentable shipwracke which happened at Plimoth in Deuonshire, on Munday the 19th. of August last past, with other great harme done elsewhere, by lightning and thunder on the same day.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The fourth of September.
NEWES FROM SVNDRY PLACES, BOTH FORRAINE AND DOMESTIQVE.
From Venice, Rome, Spaine, France, Naples, the Palatinate, and the Low-Countries.

A RELATION OF COVNT MANSFEILDS PROgre≈ø≈øe, (his battaile with Gon≈øalo in his pa≈ø≈øage) till his arriuall at Breda, with the Duke of Brun≈øwicke his valiant pur≈øuit of Gon≈øalo, (being wounded) and the ≈ølaughter of 500. of his men, and the taking of certaine Waggons, and Gon≈øaloes owne Coach.

Whereunto is added, A TRVE AND CERTAINE REPORT, OF THE LAMENTABLE SHIPWRACKE which hapned at Plimoth in Deuon≈øhire, on Munday the 19th. of Augu≈øt la≈øt pa≈øt, with other great harme done el≈øewhere, by lightning and thunder on the ≈øame day.
LONDON, Printed for Nathaniel Butter and are to be ≈øold at his Shop, at the Signe of the Pyde Bull, at Saint Au≈øtins Gate. 1622.

div.head: FROM VENICE THE thirtieth of July, 1622.
div.p: THey write from Millane that the Spani≈øh ≈øoldiers from diuers places of that State, were commanded to meet at a certaine rendeuou's, whereupon many of them were in≈øtantly charged to march towards Bormio, to oppo≈øe them≈øelues again≈øt the Gri≈øons, a troupe of them being ≈øeene at Chiavenna intending to take a Spani≈øh Po≈øt, but he was ≈øuccoured by a 150 Musketteeres, of the company of Captaine Iohn Serbelliona, which skirmi≈øhing with the Gri≈øons afore≈øaid, ≈ølue 14 of them and lo≈øt but fiue of their owne.

They had newes that the Gri≈øons hauing inuaded the higher Aguedina, many of them had be≈øieged the Fort of Sancta Maria, and the re≈øt making their excur≈øions vpon the Frontiers of the Countie of Tyroll, droue great ≈øtore of cattell from thence, into their owne territories.

And that there were daily held priuate con≈øultations, touching the departure of the Duke of Feria, (Gouernour of Millane) towards Veltolina: as likewi≈øe
that his Excellencie hauing notice that from the ≈øaid Veltolinat were fled and yet daily did fly about 60 ≈øoldiers at a time, and that (as they ≈øay) both for want of victuals and pay, he had giuen notice by a Proclamation that both Spaniards and Italians that here before abandoned the ≈øeruice of the king of Spaine, vnder what≈øoeuer pretext or colour, ≈øhould haue their pardon, returning into the ≈øame within the ≈øpace of the next en≈øuing 15 daies after the Proclamation. And tho≈øe that came not in at the prefixed time, ≈øhall be bani≈øhed and condemned to be hanged, and euery officer as well of lu≈øtice as Warre ≈øhall be authori≈øed both to take and to kill them, not exempting them that were fled them≈øelues, and afterwards reconciled.

That the Count di Monterei being there arriued, was royally lodged and entertained, at the charges of the ≈øaid Gouernor: And going to view the Ca≈øtle, the Ordnance was at his approach brauely di≈øcharged: As ≈øoone as he ≈øhall haue vi≈øited all the principall places of this city, he intends to goe on with his iourney for Spaine.
That the Gri≈øons went from Towne to Towne, to confirme their new e≈øtabli≈øhed vnion at Coyra.

And that vpon the confines of the Canton of SinZ, the Catholike Sui≈ø≈øers which haue be≈øet the pa≈ø≈øages to ≈øtop the troupes of their Enemies, had incountred one another, ≈øo that many of both ≈øides were ≈ølaine.

By particular Letters from Veltolina, we vnder≈øtand that the 26. of Iuly 30 companies of Gri≈øons and Swi≈ø≈øers, arriued in the territory of Chiavenna,
and a≈ø≈øaulting ≈øuddenly the Fort rai≈øed by the Spaniards (about a league di≈øtant from the Towne afore≈øaid) after they had killed ≈øeuen ≈øentinels of the Spani≈øh Gari≈øon before they were aware of them, they tooke it pre≈øently, and hauing put in the ≈øame 2000 men for Garri≈øon, they ≈øate downe before Chiavenna and gaue two a≈ø≈øaults to the towne, but were repul≈øed, ≈øeeing that a little before their comming, 9. companies of foot, and 3 troupes of hor≈øe were receiued in the towne. And that vpon the ≈øame day arriued at Bormio, 130 Mule a≈ø≈øes with Matches and Gunpowder, which were ≈øent from Millane for the ≈øeruice of the king of Spaine. As likewi≈øe that ≈øixe Citizens of Berganio were taken pri≈øoners in the Veltolina, intending to buy wine.

From Lyons we heare, that the French King had ≈øent Mon≈øieur de Clandibront towards Piemonte, to per≈øwade the Duke of Sauoy (as they ≈øaid) to de≈øi≈øt of his de≈øigne and enterpri≈øe vpon Momferat.

From Genua is adui≈øed, that the ≈øaid Commonwealth hauing promi≈øed vnto the Catholike King 4. Gallies (to a≈ø≈øi≈øt his other in the ≈øafe keeping of the coa≈øtes of Spaine) tooke order to ≈øend them thither.

From Vienna they write that the Diet at Odenburgh in Hungary, went well on in the behalfe of the Emperor. But that there was a rumor that Bethlem Gabor leauied new forces, none knowing there to what purpo≈øe. The Marque≈ø≈øe Gonzaga is not dead as we were informed lately, but in good health and well di≈øpo≈øed.

div.head: From Prague.
div.p: FRom Norinberg we heare, that through the Bi≈øhopricke of Bambergh, and the Marqui≈øat of An≈øpach were pa≈ø≈øed 6000 Co≈ø≈øacks, 1000 Hungarians, 1000 of the Regiment of the late decea≈øed Dampiere, as many of the Wal≈øtayni≈øh Regiment, 1000 Saxons, and 1000 of the Hol≈øtayni≈øh Regiment, being all on hor≈øe, and ≈øent to the Palatinate.

div.head: From Rome the 23. of July.
div.p: LA≈øt Sunday went the Pope to the Church of Saint Paulino, neere vnto the barefooted and reformed Carmeliton Fathers, and ≈øaid there a ≈øtill or ≈øilent Ma≈ø≈øe, in the pre≈øence of twenty Cardinals, be≈øides two Amba≈ø≈øadors, one of the Emperors, and the other of the States of Venice, and afterwards they ≈øung Te Deum Laudamus, to giue his ≈øacred maie≈øtie thanks for the victory obtained by the Bauarian Campe, and their Catholike league again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Alber≈øtadt.

The Signior Rinaldo Ario≈øti who attended the Cardinall Goradino in his Chamber, is made by the Cardinall Lodovi≈øio, great Ma≈øter of his hor≈øe, in the place of Signior Philippo Malucci, who was returned into his owne Countrey.
Signiar Ana≈øta≈øio Chianderoti of Terni is made a Collonell at Ferara, where hee was Generall before, which place was now taken from him.

The Prince of Saint Gregory, extraordinary Amba≈ø≈øador of the Duke of Parma, had wedne≈øday la≈øt audience by the Pope, and tooke his leaue to returne to his owne Principality and Lands, and from thence to the Duke dome of Parma.
The Bi≈øhop of Monte Marana in the kingdome of Naples who was come here to be examined and que≈øtioned, is lately decea≈øed.

Thur≈øday la≈øt about the euening arriued here the Auditor of Mon≈øieur Donabeto, Vice legat of that State, but we can not learne the occa≈øion which moued him to the ≈øame: And it is related that at his departure the Marque≈ø≈øe of Maletefia (Generall of the Campe) was very ≈øicke.

There was of late a di≈ø≈øention ri≈øen betwixt the Vice-roy of Naples, and the Prior Aldobrandino, Generall of the Gallies of the Pope, which hapned by a fray or tumult, betwixt the Spani≈øh watch, and ≈øome of his, who ≈øeeing that one of the Galleys was taken pri≈øoner; they re≈øcued
him againe. Whereupon the Coun≈øell of ≈øtate being called, it was pre≈øently ordered, that as many as could be gotten of them ≈øhould be clapt vp.

And hapning afterwards that a Captaine and thirty ≈øix ≈øoldiers, were taken and put in the pri≈øon within the Ca≈øtle, three Sicilians had the Stroppa de Corda, and were condemned for ten yeeres vpon the Galleys, but were pre≈øently within the ≈øpace of few daies di≈ømis'd with the re≈øt by a warrant of the Vice-roy, and went to their Galleys, ≈øayling ≈øoone after their relaxation to Me≈øsina.

But there was a Po≈øt di≈øpatch'd from hence, with a commi≈ø≈øion to cau≈øe them to returne in≈øtantly to Civita Vecchia: Seeing they were informed here, that this yeere the Turki≈øh Galleys of Bi≈øerta were not able to ≈øet forth, all their ≈ølaues and great ≈øtore of their ≈øoldiers being dead, whole Barbarie being likewi≈øe mightily inuaded with the plague: And ≈øeeing the Turks were not to bring any Nauy this yeere at Sea, it ≈øhould not bee nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øend any from Sicilia.
Here is arriued the Per≈øian Amba≈ø≈øador comming lately from Spaine.

div.head: The Copy of a Letter from Bru≈ø≈øels, dated the 23 of Aug. concerning the Progre≈ø≈øe and Re≈øolution of Count Mansfield, ≈øince his being in Lorraine. With his la≈øt Conflict and Victory with Gon≈øalo, the 19. of Aug. in Brabant.
div.p: SIr, I know you cannot be ignorant of the various reports ≈øpred abroad (throughout all the≈øe parts of Chri≈øtendome) of Count Mansfields being for the≈øe two monthes pa≈øt: Some affirming that hee is very weake; others, that he is very ≈øtrong: ≈øome, that hee ≈øhould be entertained by the French King, and that he ≈øhould be falne off from the Duke of Brun≈øwicke, vpon a breach betwixt them; and that there ≈øhould be a mutiny in their Army, whereupon they ≈øhould bee vtterly di≈øper≈øed.

Count Mansfield being pa≈ø≈øed through Loraine, (where he payed for what he tooke, and commanded his Souldiers to forbeare doing any wrong, or taking any thing from any of the Duke of Loraines Subiects; notwith≈øtanding, at a place or two his Souldiers offered ≈øome violence.) ariuing in Champaigne, made his Randeuow vpon the Frontier thereof, almo≈øt for this two monthes. In the meane time the French King made great preparation, as fearing le≈øt he ≈øhould inuade
his Countrey: but vpon triall he found him to come not as an enemy, but as one who intended to doe him ≈øeruice, and did thereupon giue command to Duke Deniuers to treate with the ≈øaid C. Mansfield vpon certaine Articles or propo≈øitions, namely, on the Kings behalfe: Deniuers propounded vnto him both honors and profits, as that he would make him a Mar≈øhall of France, and a Generall of certain forces which he would ≈øend for the recouery of the Valtoline; that he would giue him 200000. Crownes in hand, and 20000. Crownes per annum. Mansfield on the other ≈øide was to bring to the Kings ≈øeruice of his Army 6000. foot, and 2000. Hor≈øe, which ≈øhould pre≈øently receiue pay of his Maie≈øty. But Mansfield hauing a farther reach (as by the ≈øequell appeares) intends nothing el≈øe by the ≈øaid treaty, but to get him≈øelfe more aduantage, and to preuent ≈øu≈øpition in the matters which he directly intended, namely, for the ioyning with the Hollanders: For being at a towne called Mo≈øoon, on the Frontiers of France, hee gaue out of purpo≈øe that Brun≈øwicke and he were fallen out, and that he was fallen from the ≈øaid Duke of Brun≈øwicke: and had ≈øecured him≈øelfe in the ≈øtrong Towne of Mo≈øoon, and would ioyne with the French King; by which policy, the way to Brabant was the more ≈øecure, and his enemy Gon≈øalo made the le≈ø≈øe ha≈øte after him: For this treaty of his with the French King, did ≈øo amaze his enemies that they knew no other but that hee would haue concluded with him, on the contrary you ≈øhall vnder≈øtand, about the 16 day of this month, in the night (hauing before ≈øelected out 6000. of his be≈øt hor≈øe, whereof 2. thou≈øand are Carabins or light
hor≈øe, and 3000. ≈øpeciall footmen: which ≈øaid foote he likewi≈øe prouided hor≈øe for the mo≈øt part of them) marched away from Mo≈øoon vnexpected, towards Mouns in Henalt, where he ariued the 18 of this month near the Riuer of the Mozel with the D. of Brun≈øwick, leauing behind 8000. foot, and 1000. hor≈øe, with all his Canon, and the mo≈øt part of their baggage to the command of the Duke of Bulloin, and tho≈øe of the religion. On the way before they came to Mouns, they burnt and pillaged diuers villages, and ≈øacked two rich Mona≈øteries in the Archdutches dominions.

div.head: From Bru≈ø≈øels.
div.p: IT is likewi≈øe aduerti≈øed by other Letters on Saturday la≈øt, that they were come to a Ca≈øtle called Montemaria on the borders of Brabant, and that comming through Henalt the people of the Country made all the powers they could on the ≈øuddaine to re≈øi≈øt them; tho≈øe which re≈øi≈øted him were by the Man≈øfieldians put to the ≈øword, a great number of them, and the re≈øt forced to flie for their liues.

That Cordua with 8000. foot and 2000. hor≈øe, mo≈øt being Spaniards and Italians doe follow them, but are not within two daies iourney of them: Be≈øides, they cannot march halfe ≈øo farre in a day as Mansfield doth with his hor≈øe, being quit of his Canon and Baggage. Gon≈øalo had thought to haue way-laid his pa≈ø≈øage through Henalt, by ioyning his ten thou≈øand old Souldiers which tho≈øe of the Country, had not Mansfield dealt the more politiquely in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; as by this following Letter may appeare.

div.head: The Letter.
div.p: DEare and much re≈øpected friend, all the Newes that I haue to ≈øend you, is this, That Count Mansfield is come downe into Brabant, and burneth and ≈øpoyleth the countrie, marching his Army which con≈øi≈øteth of 6000. hor≈øe, and 3000. Mu≈øquiters on hor≈øebacke, for the ≈øpeedy di≈øpatching of his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

The manner of his fight is thus; The tenth man of the Mu≈øquiteers, holding the hor≈øe of the re≈øt, the re≈øt ≈øet them≈øelues in battaile: the 6000 hor≈øemen fir≈øt giues the a≈ø≈øault, and the footmen powder vpon them with their Mu≈øquiteers, whil≈øt the hor≈øemen wheele about and come in againe: and then if there be need, the Mu≈øquiteers returne againe for their ≈øuccour: if otherwi≈øe the bu≈øines bee di≈øpatched, they all on hor≈øe backe get them gone with the
prey that they deuoure and ≈øpoyle, no army of foot being able to doe any thing again≈øt them: and Spinola with all his hor≈øe being not able to make ≈øuch an army.
Brun≈øwicke comes ≈ølowly forward with a great army; Mansfield hauing made way in remouing the Ob≈øtacles for his ≈øafe pa≈ø≈øage: they are within 6. Leagues of Bru≈ø≈øels.
Hee that reported this, ≈øayth he ≈øaw Man≈øfield with his own eyes, being a Gentleman that came from the Palatinat.

div.head: A LAMENTABLE RElation of a great and fearefull ≈øtorme and Tempe≈øt, of Winde, Thunder and Lightning, Which happened in Deuon and Somer≈øet ≈øhire on Sunday and Munday the 18. and 19. day of Augu≈øt la≈øt.
div.p:
TO collect out of Stories the many and wonderfull iudgements of God from time to time ≈øhewed and executed vpon the ≈øonnes of men, is a labour beyond my purpo≈øe at this time to vndertake, and therefore I will onely relate vnto you a ≈øtory of a late wonderfull and lamentable accident, which happened in Deuon≈øhire, and there in chiefly of a ≈øhipwracke in Catwater rode by Plimouth, on Sunday night and Munday morning the 18. and 19. of Augu≈øt la≈øt. There being floting in the Rode of Catwater diuers ≈øhips, ≈øome newly ariued, others bound out for ≈øeuerall places; among the re≈øt, two Merchants ≈øhips hired by Moun≈øeur Sabe≈øa to tran≈øport certaine men for Rochell, both which ≈øhips being preparing, and partly prouided of their men, the one was ca≈øt away with other ≈øhips and barkes riding in the ≈øaid Rode afore≈øaid: The other onely buldge. But before this ≈øtorme aro≈øe, I will not omit to ≈øet downe a ≈øtrange accident which happened in one of the ≈øhips, there being in her both Mariners and Souldiers. About ≈øome three dayes before the ≈øtorme, one man in her ≈øeeming to be franticke
or ≈øicke of ≈øome violent di≈øea≈øe, required leaue to goe a ≈øhore, for his time was come and hee mu≈øt away. The Captaine notwith≈øtanding would not ≈øuffer him; in≈øomuch that the fellow ≈øaid, If they would not let him goe it would bee the wor≈øe for them all; for, ≈øaid he, doe you not ≈øee two deuils yonder, and pointed with his finger; nay, ≈øaid he, there will come three more anon. They notwith≈øtanding cau≈øed him to be bound and put in the ≈øtronge≈øt hold of the ≈øhip, vnder hatches, the hatches being clo≈øe kept downe: but about the euening when they were at prayers, hee came vp and walked on the hatches a while, whereat they were much amazed, till on a ≈øuddaine he leaped ouer board, and after him ≈øeemed to leape a thing like a great ma≈øtiffe dog; whereupon did ari≈øe ≈øuch a tempe≈øtuous ≈øtorme of wind, thunder, and lightning, that the ≈øhip wherein this mi≈øerable wretch was, left her anckers, and was ≈øplit on the Rockes, and all her men except about 8. were ca≈øt away; ≈øome of them being ca≈øt vp vpon the rockes, and a proper Gentleman among≈øt the re≈øt, was for certaine dayes ≈øtanding vpright betwixt two rockes, as though he were aliue, and impo≈ø≈øible to be got out vnle≈ø≈øe the rockes bee beaten away. In the ≈øaid rode were likewi≈øe ca≈øt away ≈øeuen other Ships & Barks, one wherof was driuen with the violence of the ≈øtorme, vpon the top of a hie rock, not much impaired, ≈øo ≈øtrangely that it is thought a thing impo≈ø≈øible it ≈øhould come there, and is as impo≈ø≈øible to be gotten off againe without ≈øpoyling, beeing driuen ≈øo farre from the water: In this ≈øtorme is reported to bee lo≈øt out of the≈øe 8. ≈øhips 300. men, be≈øides the Ships and goods. At the ≈øame time in diuers other
places be≈øides, were many ≈øhips ca≈øt away, ≈øo that it is thought the lo≈ø≈øe by ≈øhipwracke in the we≈øt parts of England is 40. or 50000. pounds.

Now concerning the hurt done by land, by thunder and lightning the ≈øame time through Deuon≈øhire and Summer≈øet≈øhire; in many places whole fields of Corne bla≈øted, ≈øtackes of Corne bla≈øted and ≈øcorched, nay the violence of the winde and thunder was ≈øuch, that is ≈øcatttered and di≈øper≈øed the Corne as if it had beene ≈øowne againe, and as if God would not ≈øuffer vs to reape the fruits of the earth, but would ≈øcatter it againe, nay out of the eares, as if the flayle had beene vpon it. Let vs compare the mildew and bla≈øting ≈øent vpon our fields in generall, in the prime of our hope, before our harue≈øt, and now in harue≈øt (vpon that litle remainder) with this ≈øudden judgement of winde and lightning, and con≈øider whether we haue not cau≈øe to repent and to feare le≈øt God may puni≈øh vs in greater mea≈øure hereafter.

div.head: From the Hage the 18. of Augu≈øt.
div.p:
That his Excellency the Prince of Orange hath prepared Stables and all other proui≈øion for 8000. hor≈øe at Breda, again≈øt the comming of Brun≈øwicke and Mansfield, and hath appointed his brother Count Henry 6000. cho≈øen foote, and 1500. ≈øpeciall hor≈øe, to make al ≈øpeed
by marching Night and Day till he meete and bee ioyned with the Duke of Brvn≈øwicke and Count Mansfield, the better to encounter with Spinola or Gonzales forces.

It is certaine that Mansfield, Brun≈øwicke, and Gonzalo haue met, but none as yet can truly report any particulars, whether hath had the greater lo≈ø≈øe, but how≈øoeuer Mansfield is Ioyned with the Prince of Orange at Breda.

That Heidelbergh, Mainbeim, and Franckendale, in regard of the Country being wa≈øted, & through feare of want of Victuals within the Townes and doubting lea≈øt the Enemy Mon≈øieur Tilly (who lyes neare them with 20000. men be≈øides 4000. Co≈ø≈øackes, Polackes, and Hungarian Hor≈øemen) ≈øhould be≈øiege them againe, are forced to turne out of their Townes all ≈øuperfluous people a≈øwell Inhabitants as others, and to leaue them to the mercifull hand of their gracious God, without who≈øe miraculous pre≈øeruation they are like to peri≈øh for want of ≈øu≈øtenance, this is all the comfort that we at this pre≈øent can affoord them, nor any other a≈ø≈øurance haue wee that our ≈øelues in ≈øhort time ≈øhall not follow them.

Leopoldus the 12. of this Month, with an Army 12000. be≈øieged Germi≈øhem or Germ≈øtadt, wherein were 500. Dutch and 200. Switzers, being the la≈øt
Towne (except the 3. former) which hath ≈øtood out vntaken, and hauing taken the ≈øame put them all to the Sword.

The Duke of Saxon hearing of ≈øome ≈øtirre ari≈øing in Site≈øia and ≈øome part of Bohemia, in the ab≈øence of the Emperour, is gone vp with Forces to preuent all danger that may happen in tho≈øe partes, before the returne of his Maie≈øty from Vienna, hee hath likewi≈øe cau≈øed 4. pieces of Cannon to be ≈øent from Prague for the be≈øieging of Glats, which yet holdes out for the King of Bohemia.

div.head: From Vienna.
div.p: That the Emperour is vpon his returne from Hungary, where hee hath receiued rea≈øonable good content. In the meane time Bethlem Gabor and the Lord Budiany are leauying of great Forces, and as ≈øome think it is by rea≈øon of the ≈øtirre of the Turks in nether Hungary, others thinke their forces are preparing to ioyne and to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Marquis Iager≈ødorp and the Count of Thorne, and to giue the Emperour his welcome home at his returne to Sile≈øia and Morauia.

div.head: From Rome.
div.p:
That Sir Robert Sherley hath beene ≈øent from the Emperour of Per≈øia to diuers Princes, and that hee is arriued heere from Spaine, and from hence hee is to go to the Princes of Jtaly, and ≈øo to the Emperor,
for ≈øoliciting them to a common League and combination again≈øt the New Turke, to ioyne their powers together for the Inuading his Dominions, now at this time hauing ≈øo faire an occa≈øion, there being a great Diui≈øion now among≈øt them.

div.head: From Venice.
div.p: That there are certaine Viceer Ba≈øhawes reuolted, and come away as farre as Adrianople, with a great number of Ships and Gallyes towards the Blacke Sea, where they are to ioyne with certaine Co≈ø≈øackes and other to make a head of Rebellion again≈øt the now pre≈øent Emperour of the Turkes.

It is likewi≈øe written, that the great Aga Gouernour of the Saraglio, hath plotted to take away the liues of O≈ømands two Brethren, the one being a Youth of a 11. yeares olde, the other of 12. but the Mother of them hauing intelligence of it, cau≈øed them to be conueyed away, by which meanes ≈øhe preuented the Con≈øpiracy, and cau≈øed the ≈øaid Aga with diuers Confederates, to be taken & Executed.

There cea≈øeth not daily to be fallings out among≈øt the Janizaries and other, which the Mu≈øti ≈øeeketh by all meanes to appea≈øe. The new Emperour the better to e≈øtabli≈øh him≈øelfe, hath made choy≈øe of the Ba≈øhaw of Cayro to bee his chiefe Viceer Ba≈øhaw, vnto whom he hath giuen his Si≈øter in Mariage,
being a very di≈øcreet experienced man, and on who is like to ≈øettle Peace and quiet in the Citty of of Con≈øtantinople, if not in all Turky be≈øides.

The King of Spaine hath taken vp the 15. of this Month, 300000. Crownes more, and cau≈øed it to be ≈øent to Antwerpe for the payment of Spinola his Souldiers. Tho≈øe of Genoway haue likewi≈øe granted to lend the King of Spaine 4. Gallyes furni≈øhed vnder the Commaund of Prince Doria, with other Gallyes from the Pope and the Duke of Florence, with tho≈øe of Malta for the a≈ø≈øi≈øting of him again≈øt the Pirates of Argier, who are ≈øaid to bee Ioyned with the Hollander, and haue made a great Nauy, wherewith they haue inuaded ≈øome part of the King of Spaines Territories, ouer again≈øt the Coa≈øt of Barbary, rather then the Iland of Mamora, as was formerly ≈øu≈øpected.

div.head: From France.
div.p:
His Maie≈øty hauing (him≈øelfe in per≈øon) taken the Towne of Louening in Lanquedocke, betwixt Ca≈øtres and Mountaubon, The chiefe Citizens comming foorth of the Towne and meeting the King with the Keyes of the Gates in their hands, being vpon tearmes of Compo≈øition, did for their re≈øi≈øtance cau≈øe them to bee Hanged, and likewi≈øe cau≈øed a great number of the Towne to bee put to the
Sword, vpon the yeelding vp of the ≈øame.

Likewi≈øe it is ≈øaid, that hee hath taken in the Towne of Semers, a Towne of great con≈øequence to tho≈øe of the Religion, ≈øince he hath made Duke Dediguires Generall of his Army, and Gouernor of Dolphin, who before was but Lieutenant, and in his place is his Sonne in Law Mon≈øieur Criki made Lieutenant of Dolphini, who is now gone to be≈øiege Mompelier with 20. pieces of Cannon.

The ≈øaid Dediguiers treating with Duke de Roban, offered him very Honourable conditions, if hee will lay downe his Armes and come vnto his Maie≈øty, who as yet bides con≈øtant and his Army encrea≈øeth daily, and that he prepares for the remouing of the Siege.

It is certainely written from France, that Mon≈øieur Chatilion is reuolted to the Kings ≈øide, being before Commander of a Towne called Egremorts belonging to Prote≈øtants, which hee hath deliuered vp, and whereupou he is made one of the Mar≈øhals of France, and is at this pre≈øent in the Kings Army with Dedigueirs, at the ≈øiege of Mompelier, or rather of Ca≈øtres, being hard by Mompelier, & more ea≈øie to be taken.

div.head: From Rochell the 8. of Augu≈øt.
div.p:
A French Marchant arriuing heere in London on Saturday la≈øt, reporteth as followeth: That when
hee came from thence it was the 18. of this in≈øtant Month, hee left in the Citty of Rochell 5000. braue Souldiers of ≈øeuerall Nations, be≈øides the Inhabitants and tho≈øe Souldiers of the Citty, viz. of Engli≈øh, Scots, Dutch and French, ouer whom Mon≈øieur de Fauours is Commander, a man of great Experience and Valour, in the former Kings warres, who doth daily ≈øalley out of the Town both with hor≈øe and foote, defeating the aduer≈øe part, and bringing in Cattle and other proui≈øion daily.

The Count of Soy≈øons being Commander of the Kings Army, hath built a Fort and mounted a piece of Cannon thereupon, whereby he hath annoyed ≈øome of the highe≈øt built hou≈øes in the Towne, but through often ≈øhooting off, 4. or 5. of the ≈øaid Cannons are become vn≈øeruiceable, being broken.

The Towne on the other ≈øide haue done the Kings Army greater hurt, and haue them≈øelues taken and made vn≈øeruiceable diuers of the Kings Cannon, and haue poy≈øoned all the Fountaines round about the Citty neere the Army, whereby the Souldiers of Count de Soy≈øons dye daily, but they haue (in regard of the re≈øpect and Honor they beare him) aduerti≈øed the ≈øaid Count thereof, that be may the better auoyde the ≈øame.

The ≈øame Marchant reports what hee likewi≈øe ≈øaw? comming from Rochell in the ≈øaid Riuer were
16. Ships (accu≈øtomed to goe to New found Land) prepared and furni≈øhed ready for Warliike ≈øeruice, and were appointed to goe and encounter with the King his Gallyes where≈øoeuer they ≈øhall meete, and ≈øayling further ≈øome 10. Leagues from Rochell neere the Ile de Deu, came by the Kings Fleete con≈øi≈øting of 46. Sayle of Ships, be≈øides 13. expected from St. Malloes, with 10. Gallyes of Burwayes, all which Ships makes 59. Sayle, the 10. Gallyes being appointed to meete with the 16. Fi≈øher Ships, as afore≈øaid, The Rochell Fleete at the ≈øame time being but 40. Ships ioyned, but expected 20. more hourely from the Ile of Rees to come to them, and being within 8. Leagues of the Kings Fleete, ≈øince which time there is newes come to my Lord the French Amba≈ø≈øadour, that within 4. dayes after this Marchant pa≈ø≈øed by them, the two Fleetes met and had a cruell Fight, but the particulars where of and who had the better are not yet knowne, for within 3. dayes after, the Secretary of State at Paris had notice of the ≈øame, but could not vnder≈øtand the particulars, nor who had the better of it.

div.head: The Coppy of a Letter from Breda.
div.p: Count Mansfield hauing intelligence of Don Cordua's Approach, ≈øent certaine Troopes to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe ≈øome pa≈ø≈øage to hinder his March, but the≈øe loo≈øing the direct way were defeated and put to flight by the Forces of the Bi≈øhop of Liege, whereupon Count Mansfield re≈øolued to≈øolued to march with his whole Army to the afore≈øaid pa≈ø≈øage, being there arriued, the Enemy appeared in ≈øight, pre≈øently Count Mansfield burned his Baggage and prepared to the Battaile, which continued long and furious, in the end Don Coraua was forced to retire, & in the retreat the Duke of Brun≈øwicke was ≈øhot and hurt, whereat being inraged the more in regard hee was wounded in the Enemies retreat, he di≈øarmed him≈øelfe and ≈øhifted his Beuer, thus onely with his Hat and Ca≈ø≈øocke hee made choi≈øe of ≈øome Regiments, and with them re≈øolutely a≈ø≈øayled the retiring Enemy, ≈ølew 500. of their men, and ≈øeazed vpon ≈øundry Waggons richly laden, and al≈øo tooke Don Cordua's owne Coach, wherein the Duke made to the Hage in Triumph.

It is al≈øo certified from a Commaunder in Borgen, that Count Mansfield hauing ≈øurpri≈øed two pieces of Cannon of the Enemies, he afterwards tooke a Coach of Don Cordua's wherein was a good quantity of pieces of Siluer of value 5. ≈øhillings Sterling, wherewith Count Mansfield in a Brauado charged their owne Ordinance, and ≈ølew many of them with their owne Coyne.
